content.description: Great slab with many fun variations.
content.location: Just above the Jormungandr in the gully.

content.description: On the backside of the warm-up slab boulder (it faces the road).  Start sitting on a cool jug feature. climb up and right on some technical/powerful moves.
Climb the arete, starting with a right hand sloper/crimp on the arete and a left hand crimp on the face both at head height.
content.location: Obvious boulder on RHS of the gully (up and right from lizard head wall)

content.description:
Fun weird problem on the pac-man shaped boulder by KGB.

Start under the lip on the S / downhill side near the right arete and go straight up without using the arete.

may be another name out there but there’s no guide for these so this seems like a good name.
content.location: PAC-MAN boulder, straight up the trail about 50 yds from the road. Don’t turn left on the trail that goes up to Sundial, stay straight and you’ll see a clearing with a few boulders.

content.description:
Jormungandr was a Norse Mythology serpent so big that it encircled the world. This line is also big and swooping (though not super dangerous!). This is a beautiful boulder, and an obvious line that climbs nearly as well as it looks, though it can be a little toothy and flaky. I don't think anyone has done it since I did it in April 2018. (edit - repeated by J Keener in 2021), and others have now been up trying it.

Campus start on the lowest holds on left side, under the slabs. Traverse right along the lip, and then finish on the stand start of this boulder.

J Keener showed me this boulder, and invited me to do it first. Thanks J! Brett, Brice, and Deanna helped to hike pads and spot me. Thanks!

Let me know about the difficulty. I'm not invested in it being a certain grade.
content.protection: Nice to have 6-7 pads. It's long, the middle is rocky, and the end is a bit tall.
content.location: Halfway up to Sundial, you will see this large boulder.

content.description: Large arete with quarry work on the left side for holds up to a shot hole out right then up to the top.
content.protection: Bring a BIG pad. There is a good constructed landing, but if you blew it up high you're probably going to get hurt.
content.location:
Park just up the canyon from the LDS archive road.

Take the trail up the hill as if you are headed up to Lizard Head wall. As you follow the cairns soon you will come out of the trees and see this boulder up to your right in the gully.

content.description:
Tall, beautiful, and finishes with a mildly committing rockover at 15 feet or so. This is among the better lines in Lizard Head.

Mike mentioned that he never named this line, but it has become known as "Concussed" since the FA.

Also look for the lower start to Concussed, which is similarly awesome, and the lowest start, Jormungandr, which is a new school LCC classic.
content.protection: Nice to have 3-4 pads. Good place to roll an ankle.
content.location: This is the stand start to Jormungandr. The most obvious place to start is with a decent left hand sloper, and undercut right hand edge, and then pop your heel way up and left. Then drive up the arete and finish on the rad rockover.

content.description: The middle start on the Jormungandr boulder. Great movement, and the rock is cleaning up nicely.
content.protection: 5-6 pads and a spotter is nice.
content.location: Jormungandr boulder, which is on the trail about 10 minutes walk up the Lizard Head area.

climbs.name: A Simple Misunderstanding
climbs.fa: First Vision: Vic Copland  First Ascent: Tommy Rigby/J Keener

content.description: Sit start to Sundial. Left hand on arete, right hand on sloper 18 inches right of arete.

A neat problem which has a few different solutions, seemingly one of the token invert boulders in LCC. Start inverted on heel-toe cams laying down in the back of the little cave, work up and pull around. The amount you use (or don't use) the drill holes and inverted / offwidth technique is up to you.

Stumbled across this problem in Danny Parker's old blog. There's two good pictures of this problem there.

http://offwidtharmy.blogspot.com/2015/03/boulders-that-touch.html?m=1

No idea what the grade is, maybe easier, maybe harder?
content.location: In the obvious, short overhanging offwidth just off the trail
